channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Disaster in Search of an Investigation
item.description: For all of the diplomatic frenzy that has followed the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, there is no sign of an investigation at the crash site.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers walked amid the unguarded wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, which was shot down over eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Blasts Kill 16 Seeking Haven at Gaza School
item.description: A series of explosions at a school that was sheltering hundreds of Palestinians who had fled their homes also wounded many others. The cause was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Weather Suspected in Air Algérie Plane Wreck; 116 Are Feared Dead
item.description: Officials said the jet, which took off from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, went down during a storm in a semidesert area.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Official Vents Outrage at Shelling of U.N. Schools in Gaza
item.description: The United Nations had given the Israeli military precise GPS locations of all 83 schools that were being used as shelters for 141,000 people who had fled their homes.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Iraq Picks New President to Confront Militant Threat
item.description: Fouad Massoum, a Kurd, was chosen and immediately sworn in amid a growing Sunni insurgency and international calls for a more inclusive government.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and SUADAD AL-SALHY

item.title: Ukraine Prime Minister Resigns as Key Coalition in Parliament Falls Apart
item.description: The moves suggested that President Petro O. Poroshenko and his allies were optimistic that the insurrection would soon be quashed.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk of Ukraine resigned on Thursday.

item.title: Spectators to War, West Bank Residents Hail the Hamas Fight Against Israel
item.description: Many in the West Bank are cheering Hamas for its armed resistance, and excoriating the Palestinian Authority for its failure to win statehood.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Palestinians fire weapons during a funeral in the West Bank on Tuesday.

item.title: In Spain, Government Cars With an Unsavory Past
item.description: Spanish officials are using armored cars seized from criminals, saying the vehicles are not only a big improvement but also a cost saver.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Washington Post Reporter Apparently Detained in Iran
item.description: A Washington Post correspondent, his Iranian wife and two other Americans were apparently taken into custody on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: China’s Plan to Limit Coal Use Could Spur Consumption for Years
item.description: Under pressure to reduce smog and carbon emissions, China is considering a mandatory cap on coal use, but it would be an adjustable ceiling and would allow coal consumption to grow for years.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant on the outskirts of Datong, in Shanxi Province.

item.title: Lens Blog: A Graphic Photo Spurs Reflection
item.description: The image of two Indian girls – victims of gang rape – hanged from a tree has inspired discussion on the use and impact of such a graphic image.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: The cropped image, as it appeared on a New York Times mobile app.

item.title: Ukraine Crisis Is Testing E.U.’s Resolve
item.description: As it considers sanctions against Russia, the European Union faces a question: Can it reconcile competing interests, confront a conflict on its borders and play a meaningful role in foreign policy?
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and ALAN COWELL

item.title: U.S. Considering Refugee Status For Hondurans
item.description: The plan aims to stem the surge at the border, allowing hundreds of minors and young adults to enter the United States without making a dangerous trek through Mexico.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants traveling north through Mexico toward the United States on a northbound freight train known as “The Beast,” because of rampant accidents and violent crime.

item.title: Spared Sudanese Christian Woman Meets Pope in Rome
item.description: The pope spent half an hour speaking with Meriam Ibrahim, whose death sentence in Sudan for refusing to renounce her faith set off an international protest.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis greets Meriam Ibrahim and her daughter Maya.

item.title: At a Spanish Border, a Coordinated Scramble
item.description: African migrants said they camped out for months to study the border guards' patterns as they prepared to scale the fences and enter Europe.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Santi Palacios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spanish police, in the foreground, and Moroccan police, in the background, blocked dozens of African migrants as they attempted to jump a fence separating Morocco from the Spanish enclave of Melilla last month as part of an attempt to cross into Spain.

item.title: Court Censures Poland Over C.I.A. Renditions
item.description: The European Court of Human Rights rules that by allowing the transfer of two terrorism suspects to a secret C.I.A. site in Poland, the country violated the men’s rights.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Investigators Examine Role of Weather in Taiwan Plane Crash
item.description: A spokesman for the Aviation Safety Council of Taiwan said it was too early to determine the role of the storm in the crash, but the airline said that the weather was a factor.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Flights to and From Israel Can Resume, Regulators Say
item.description: American and European air safety officials said Israel had taken adequate safety precautions to allow flights to resume.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: At War Blog: In Ukraine, Spent Cartridges Offer Clues to Violence Fueled by Soviet Surplus
item.description: Samples of cartridge cases gathered by two reporters for The New York Times in eastern Ukraine showed that ammunition for assault rifles used in the clashes originated in plants that once were mainstays of Soviet arms production.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: C. J. Chivers/The New York Times
item.media:description: An expended rifle cartridge removed from bloody puddle, before, left, and after cleaning, which showed that it had been manufactured in Ulyanovsk, the city of Lenin’s birth, in 1982.

item.title: Letter From Europe: David Cameron Stumbles Over Russia’s Tripwire
item.description: David Cameron is discovering that Russia is not simply, as Winston Churchill put it in 1939, “a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma.”
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a news conference in London in June 2013.

item.title: China’s Energy Plans Will Worsen Climate Change, Greenpeace Says
item.description: Two operational coal-to-gas plants in China and 48 proposed ones would together emit an estimated 1.1 billion tons of carbon dioxide per year, Greenpeace said.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Australia Offers 50 Police Officers to Secure Jet Crash Site in Ukraine
item.description: Australia, which lost dozens of citizens on Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, has sent 50 police officers to Europe in hopes that they will be allowed to help secure the crash site in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: 2 Foreign Aid Workers Are Gunned Down in Afghanistan, Officials Say
item.description: Two women from Finland employed by an international aid organization were shot dead Thursday morning in the western city of Herat, Afghan officials said.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: More Than 60 Killed in Attack on Iraqi Prison Convoy
item.description: Several explosions targeting the convoy north of the capital in the early morning and an ensuing gunfight left more than 60 people dead.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and SUADAD AL-SALHY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: How I Passed the English Cricket Test
item.description: We often overlook the fluid and contradictory reality of people’s actual identities.
item.dc:creator: By KENAN MALIK
